Manifest.Name: Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System

DataSource.RegExpFilter: \s+su: \S+\(\S+\): session opened for user root by \S+\(uid=[[:digit:]]+\)

Diagnostic.Comment: In response to High CPU Utilization, Return top Consumers
In response to High CPU Utilization, Return top Consumers
In response to High Memory Utilization, Return top Consumers
In response to High Memory Utilization, Return top Consumers

ProbeAction.Input: <p:ExecuteCommand_INPUT xmlns:p="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wscim/1/cim-schema/2/SCX_OperatingSystem"><p:command>sh -c 'ps -ef | grep auditd | grep -v grep | grep -v kauditd' </p:command><p:timeout>60</p:timeout></p:ExecuteCommand_INPUT>

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer" with instances of computers that are running a Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer Group" with instances of computers that are running a Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule deploys the bundled Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 agent packages to Management Servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Direct login using the root account password detected.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Users may have been granted access to privileged accounts. This alerting rule allows system administrators to track direct logins using the root account password.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If this event appears suspicious, check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: An SSH authentication failure for the root account has been detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure may be caused by a mistyped password or an attempt to use an invalid username. However, a persistent failure could be an indication that someone is attempting to gain unauthorized access.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the problem encountered. If a failure occurs, check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this failure to diagnose the problem.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A failed 'su' command has been detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unsuccessful attempt was made to elevate privileges with 'su.' This may have been caused by a mistyped password or an attempt to use an invalid username. However, a persistent failure could be an indication of suspicious activity.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If 'su' usage appears suspicious, check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A successful 'su' command has been detected in the system log files.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Users may have been granted access to privileged accounts with 'su' elevation. This alerting rule allows system administrators to track 'su' usage.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: The description of the alert and/or the output data item contains information on the event encountered. If 'su' usage appears suspicious, check the associated event details and any other events that happened around the time of this event.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Logical Disk" with instances of logical disks discovered on Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: The discovery of logical disks (file systems) can be customized through the use of exclusion regular expressions for the file system name and type. Any matching file systems with a name matching the Exclude File System Name Expression or type matching the Exclude File System Type Expression parameters are excluded from discovery.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Logical Disk Bytes/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of bytes per second transferred to or from the logical disk (file system) during write or read operations.
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A logical disk (file system) that was previously online is no longer available.

File system health is determined by inspecting the mount table to identify permanent, mounted file systems. If a mounted file system identified in a previous iteration is not included in the current enumeration, it is considered unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that a file system has gone offline. This may be caused by a disk being unmounted.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Inspect the Logical Disk in the Health Explorer. Health Explorer provides the critical information and a mechanism to remount a file system. You can remount a file system from Health Explorer using the 'Disk Health Mount' recovery task.
Optionally, you can use the Logical Disk description provided by the Health Explorer to manually mount the file system on the affected host with the 'mount' command.
To view file system health you can use the following view:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Disk Read Bytes/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of bytes per second transferred from the logical disk (file system) during read operations.
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Disk Reads/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of reads per second performed on the logical disk (file system).
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Disk Transfers/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of transfers (both read and write operations) per second that were performed on the logical disk (file system).
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Disk Write Bytes/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of bytes per second transferred to the logical disk (file system) during write operations.
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Disk Writes /sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of writes per second performed on the logical disk (file system).
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Free Megabytes performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of unallocated space on a specific logical disk (file system) in megabytes.

The file system space reserved for the root user is not included in the calculated free space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The amount of free space on the logical disk (file system) is low. System performance may be adversely affected, and the ability to add or modify existing files on the file system may be at risk until additional free space is made available.

The file system space reserved for the root user is not included in the calculated free space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Separate threshold values can be set for Warning and Error states. Since file systems may vary in size from a few gigabytes to many terabytes, the Logical Disk Free Space monitor requires that an Operator indicate both the megabyte and percentage threshold values. Both megabyte and percentage thresholds must be passed before the Warning and Error thresholds are reached.

This monitor is disabled by default. It can be enabled with an override, targeting specific Logical Disk instances or all Logical Disk instances. If this monitor is enabled, the Logical Disk % Free Space monitor should be disabled with an override.
Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When existing files grow in size and the new files are added, the free space is taken up on a file system. When the amount of free space on the file system falls below the threshold, the state for the Logical Disk will change.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To increase the amount of available space, do one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: View the disk capacity from the Operations Manager console. Determine if any new applications have been recently installed.
Review any log files for logs that appear to be excessively large. If so, determine if the logs are current or historical logs. Consider creating compressed archives of historical log files.
Back up and remove files, or delete unnecessary files from the file system.
Move files to another file system or to offline storage.

maml:section.maml:para: To view recent file system capacity history you can use the following view:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\% Free Inodes performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of the total inodes on the selected file system that are free.

If the file system does not use inodes, the percent free inodes value is returned as 100 percent. File system inode usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate inodes, such as JFS.
This rule is disabled by default. It can be enabled with an override, targeting specific Logical Disk instances or all Logical Disk instances.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The percentage of free inodes on the logical disk (file system) is low. System performance may be adversely affected, and the ability to add files on the file system may be at risk until additional inodes are made available.

If the file system does not use inodes, the Percent Free Inodes value is returned as 100 percent. File system inode usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate inodes, such as JFS.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the percentage of free inodes is currently low. This is likely caused by an excessive number of files stored on the file system.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Inodes store metadata about files and directories. If all available inodes for a file system are allocated, new files and directories cannot be created, even if free space is available. To resolve a low percent of free inodes condition, inspect the file system and look for unused files and directories that can be deleted or moved to an alternate file system.
To view recent file system capacity history you can use the following view:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\% Free Space performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of the total usable space on the selected logical disk (file system) that is free.

The file system space reserved for the root user is not included in the calculated free space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.
This rule is disabled by default. It can be enabled with an override, targeting specific Logical Disk instances or all Logical Disk instances.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The percentage of free space on the logical disk (file system) is low. System performance may be adversely affected, and the ability to add or modify existing files on the file system may be at risk until additional free space is made available.

The file system space reserved for the root user is not included in the calculated free space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average.

This monitor has been superseded by the corresponding Logical Disk Free Space monitor, which implements configurable Warning and Error free space thresholds by both percentage and megabyte. If the corresponding Logical Disk Free Space monitor is enabled, disable this monitor with an override.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When existing files grow in size and the new files are added, the free space is taken up on a file system. When the amount of free space on the file system falls below the threshold, the state for the Logical Disk will change.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To increase the amount of available disk space, do one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: View the disk capacity from the Operations Manager console. Determine if any new applications have been recently installed.
Review any log files for logs that appear to be excessively large. If so, determine if the logs are current or historical logs. Consider creating compressed archives of historical log files.
Back up and remove files, or delete unnecessary files from the file system.
Move files to another file system or to offline storage.

maml:section.maml:para: To view recent file system capacity history you can use the following view:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\% Used Inodes performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of the total usable inodes on the selected file system that are currently allocated.

If the file system does not use inodes, the percent used inodes value is returned as 0 percent. File system inode usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate inodes, such as JFS.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\% Used Space performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of the total usable space on the selected logical disk (file system) that is currently allocated.

The file system space reserved for the root user is included in the calculated used space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Logical Disk\Used Megabytes performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of allocated space on a specific logical disk (file system) in megabytes.

The file system space reserved for the root user is included in the calculated used space. File system space usage is calculated with current free and total values, which may not accurately represent true usage for file systems that dynamically allocate space, such as ZFS.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Logical Disk Capacity Analysis report displays a chart for the following Performance counters:
The report finds data if the objects supplied are of the type:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Logical Disk
The report displays a chart and data table for each object. The report shows a chart with hourly aggregation.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Logical Disk object types.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Select the target Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Logical Disk in a State or Performance view.
Date/Time selection: Allows the selection of a relative or fixed date, time range and time zone.
Business hours: Allows the filtering of results to one set of business hours for a defined number of weekdays.
Object: Allows the adding of objects to run this report against.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Adapter\Bytes Received/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the number of bytes per second received over the network adapter, including framing characters.

The value returned by the agent is a cumulative counter of bytes received for the network adapter. The rule calculates the delta of bytes between successive samples (where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation) and divides this delta value by the number of seconds between the sample collection times.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Adapter\Bytes Sent/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the number of bytes per second sent over the network adapter, including framing characters.

The value returned by the agent is a cumulative counter of bytes sent for the network adapter. The rule calculates the delta of bytes between successive samples (where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation) and divides this delta value by the number of seconds between the sample collection times.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Network Adapter\Bytes Total/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the number of bytes per second sent and received over the network adapter, including framing characters.

The value returned by the agent is a cumulative counter of bytes sent and received for the network adapter. The rule calculates the delta of bytes between successive samples (where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation) and divides this delta value by the number of seconds between the sample collection times.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the Linux Computer class named "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Network Adapter" with instances of Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Network Adapters.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The network adapter has been disconnected from the network and no longer has network connectivity.

Network adapter health is determined by identifying network adapters that are Up or Running (as defined by the device flags: IFF_RUNNING and IFF_UP of the ioctl: SIOCGIFFLAGS). If a network adapter that was identified as Up or Running is no longer Up or Running, it is considered unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Your computer's network adapter lost its connection to the network.

The adapter's connection to the network can be lost if you remove a network cable from your network adapter or if you are roaming between wireless access points with a mobile system. Other possible causes include network issues, firewall issues, or a malfunction of the network adapter or its driver.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If your computer is connected to the network by cable, confirm that the cable is plugged in properly. If you have a wireless network connection, confirm that you have a signal and the proper credentials for the wireless network.
If the network connection is working properly, check the following possible causes and take corrective action:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The network is down. Attempt to ping or traceroute to the host.
The firewall on your computer is blocking network broadcast traffic.
Your computer's network adapter or driver is not functioning correctly. Login to the system as root and type 'ifconfig -a' to view all available network interfaces.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Available MBytes Memory performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the amount of memory, in megabytes, immediately available for allocation to a process or for system use.
The available megabytes memory value represents the sum of MemFree, Buffers and Cached, as reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Available megabytes of memory is low. System performance may be adversely affected.
The available megabytes memory value represents the sum of MemFree, Buffers and Cached, as reported by the operating system.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The amount of available physical memory can become low under the following circumstances:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Too many applications/processes are running simultaneously on the computer.
An application may be leaking memory over time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address a low physical memory condition an administrator may choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Stop or kill one or more applications or processes. To inspect resources used by processes, use the "top" command and enter the interactive command "m" to see memory utilization.
Add physical memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:para: You can view available memory by running the "Memory Information" Task from the State View.
You can view detailed memory statistics by running the "Run VMStat" Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Swap Space\Available MBytes Swap performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of available swap space in megabytes.
The available megabytes of swap space value represents the free swap space, as reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Available megabytes of swap space is low. System performance may be adversely affected.
The available megabytes of swap space value represents the free swap space, as reported by the operating system.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the swap space utilization is currently high. Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Processes using excessive physical memory resources.
Writing to a temp file system.
Too many applications are running simultaneously on the computer.
An application may be leaking memory over time.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions

maml:listItem.maml:para: Stop or kill one or more applications or processes. To inspect resources used by processes, use the "top" command and enter the interactive command "m" to see memory utilization.

Add swap space. Using mkfile, create a file for local swap area. To create a 1GB swap file, execute: dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1k count=1048576. Issue the command to make it a swap file: mkswap /swapfile. Issue the command to activate the swap file: swapon /swapfile. You can run the 'free' command to see all available swap space.
Add physical memory to the computer.

maml:section.maml:para: You can view available memory by running the "Memory Information" Task from the State View.
You can view detailed memory statistics by running the "Run VMStat" Task from the State View.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System" with instances of discovered Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 operating systems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Page Reads/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the number of read operations per second against the disk to resolve hard page faults. This counter shows read operations, without regard to the number of pages retrieved in each operation. This counter is a primary indicator for the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Pages/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the number of pages per second read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults, and it is a primary indicator of the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Page Writes/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the number of write operations per second written to disk to free up space in physical memory. This counter shows write operations, without regard to the number of pages written in each operation. This counter is a primary indicator for the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\% Available Memory performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of available memory as a percentage of the total memory on the system.
The percentage of available memory value is calculated by comparing the available memory (MemFree, Buffers and Cached) and total physical memory values reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Swap Space\% Available Swap Space performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of available swap space as a percentage of the total swap space on the system.
The percentage of available swap space value is calculated by comparing the free and total swap space values reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\% Used Memory performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of memory currently in use by the system as a percentage of the total memory on the system.
The percentage of used memory value is calculated by subtracting available memory (MemFree, Buffers and Cached) from total physical memory, and comparing to the total physical memory value.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Swap Space\% Used Swap Space performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of used swap space as a percentage of the total swap space on the system.
The percentage of used swap space value is calculated by subtracting free swap space from total swap space and comparing to the total swap space value reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% DPC Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the percentage of time that all processors spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The total percentage of DPC time (for all processors) is high. System performance may be adversely affected.

Total DPC time is the time that all processors spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average. The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A high DPC time condition can be caused by one or more of the following:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Hardware or device driver related problem

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To determine the root cause of a high DPC time condition, follow the process outlined below. Observe the proportion of the processor time that is spent servicing interrupts and DPCs. To do this, monitor the following metrics:
Compare the values of the % Interrupt Time (_Total) and % DPC Time (_Total) metrics to % Processor Time (_Total).

If the sustained % Processor Time (_Total) is > 85% and the % Interrupt Time (_Total) or % DPC Time (_Total) is > 15%, the processors are probably the source of a performance bottleneck. This bottleneck can be addressed by upgrading or adding processors to the computer.

If the sustained % Processor Time (_Total) is < 85% and the % Interrupt Time (_Total) or Total % DPC Time (_Total) is > 15%, the performance issue may be the result of either an application or hardware related issue.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Idle Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors spent running the idle thread.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Interrupt Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the time that all processors spent receiving and servicing hardware interrupts. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, storage controllers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention. Normal thread execution is suspended during interrupts.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The total percentage of interrupt time (for all processors) is high. System performance may be adversely affected.

Total interrupt time is the time that all processors spent receiving and servicing hardware interrupts. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, storage controllers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention. Normal thread execution is suspended during interrupts.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average. The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A high interrupt time condition most often indicates that there is a problem with a hardware device.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: System log files should be checked to identify device errors.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% IO Wait Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors were running the idle thread while the system had an outstanding disk I/O request.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Nice Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors spent running processes with changed nice values in user mode.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Privileged Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors spent running code in privileged mode.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Processor Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors spent running a non-idle thread. Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run. This metric is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The total percentage of processor time (for all processors) is high. System performance may be adversely affected.

Total processor time is the time that all processors spent running a non-idle thread. Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run. This metric is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average. The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the processor utilization is currently high. This may be caused by an application using excessive processor resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address high processor time conditions choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Identify processes that are running when the processor time is at the highest. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. This task provides a listing of the top CPU consuming processes ordered by CPU usage.
Stop or kill any unnecessary identified processes.
Add processors or physical memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% User Time (_Total) performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that all processors spent running code in user mode. Applications and most system utilities execute in user mode.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Swap Space\Used MBytes Swap performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of used swap space in megabytes.
The megabytes of used swap space value is calculated by subtracting the free swap space from total swap space values reported by the operating system.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Memory\Used Memory MBytes performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the total amount of memory currently in use by the system in megabytes.
The used megabytes memory value is calculated by subtracting available memory (MemFree, Buffers and Cached) from total physical memory.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operating System Configuration report displays these discovered properties:
The report finds data if the objects supplied are of the type:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating system
The report displays a matrix detailing all the found properties.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object types.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Select the target Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer or Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object in a State or Performance view.
Date/Time selection: Allows the selection of a relative or fixed date, time range and time zone.
Object: Allows the adding of objects to run this report against.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operating System Performance report displays one chart with these performance items:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Swap Space: Percent Used Swap Space

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of the type:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System
The report displays a chart and data table for each object. The report shows a chart with hourly aggregation.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object types.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Select the target Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer or Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object in a State or Performance view.
Date/Time selection: Allows the selection of a relative or fixed date, time range and time zone.
Object: Allows the adding of objects to run this report against.

maml:section.maml:para: The Operating System Performance History report displays one chart with these performance items:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Swap Space: Percent Used Swap Space

maml:section.maml:para: The report finds data if the objects supplied are of the type:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System
The report displays a chart and data table for each object. The report shows a historical chart with "Monthly by Days" aggregation.
When run from the Reporting space:
The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object types.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Select the target Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer or Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating System object in a State or Performance view.
Date/Time selection: Allows the selection of a relative or fixed date, time range and time zone.
Object: Allows the adding of objects to run this report against.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Operating System Storage Configuration report displays these discovered properties:
The report finds data if the objects supplied are of the type:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer
The report displays a matrix detailing all the found properties.
When run from the Reporting space:

The second column in the search results shows of which type the displayed objects are. Make sure you select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Logical Disk object types, or choose 'Add Group' and select Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer object types.
When run from the Monitoring space:
Select the target Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computer object in a State or Performance view.
Date/Time selection: Allows the selection of a relative or fixed date, time range and time zone.
Object: Allows the adding of objects to run this report against.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Avg. Disk sec/Read performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average time, in seconds, of disk reads. A disk that is developing a bottleneck might cause the entire system to slow.
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.
Monitoring of physical disks is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Physical Disks.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The average time per read (for the physical disk) is high. System performance may be adversely affected.
The average physical disk time per read is measured in seconds. A disk that is developing a bottleneck might cause the entire system to slow.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average. The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Monitoring of physical disks is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Physical Disks.'
Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the physical disk average time per read is currently high.
Circumstances that may cause this condition:

maml:listItem.maml:para: High processor utilization can cause slowdowns when doing large data transfers.
The hard drive interface speed can form a bottleneck to overall performance if it is too low for the hard disk's maximum sustained transfer rate.
When available memory is low, the Virtual Memory Manager writes more pages to swap, resulting in increased disk activity.
Upgrade to a faster processor or add processors.
Confirm system has the maximum speed hard drive that it can support.

Be sure to set this threshold value appropriately for your specific storage hardware. The appropriate threshold value varies according to the disk's underlying storage subsystem. For example, the "disk" might be a single spindle or a large disk array. You can use overrides to define exception thresholds, which can be applied to specific computers or entire computer groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Physical Disk" with instances of physical disks discovered on Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Physical Disk\Physical Disk Bytes/sec performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the average number of bytes per second transferred to or from the physical disk during write or read operations.
The value returned by the agent is the average rate for the preceding 5 minutes.
Monitoring of physical disks is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Physical Disks.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: A physical disk that was previously available is no longer available.

Physical disk health is determined by inspecting the physical disks associated with mounted file systems. If a physical disk that was available in a previous iteration is not included in the current enumeration, it is considered unhealthy.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Monitoring of physical disks is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Physical Disks.'
Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that a physical disk has gone offline. This may be caused by disk cable, controller, or power related failures, as well as actual physical disk failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Analyze system logs to determine the cause of the failure.
To view physical disk health you can use the following view:

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers supported agent information for Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 on PowerPC computers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The audit daemon is not running. Check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.
The audit daemon facilitates the writing of audit records to disk.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the audit daemon is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep auditd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running the command "systemctl start auditd" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system log file (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Cron daemon is not running. Check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.
The Cron daemon facilitates scheduled command execution.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the Cron daemon is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running 'ps -ef | grep cron' or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. If it is down, you can start the process using the command 'systemctl restart crond' or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system log files (/var/log/messages) and (/var/log/cron), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The SSH daemon is not running. Check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.
The daemon for SSH is named sshd. It provides secure encrypted communication between two untrusted hosts over an insecure network. There should be at least one process running at all times.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the SSH daemon is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep sshd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running the command "systemctl start sshd" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system log files (/var/log/messages) and (/var/log/secure), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Syslog daemon is not running. Check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.
The Syslog daemon implements message logging and forwarding to files and users.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the Syslog daemon is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service on the system by running 'ps -ef | grep rsyslogd' or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. If it is down, you can start the process using the command 'systemctl restart rsyslog' or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system log file (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The udev daemon is not running. Check the Diagnostic and Recovery results to see if further action is required.
Udev is a generic kernel device manager. It runs as a daemon on a Linux system and listens to events the kernel sends out if a new device is initialized or installed.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: A failure indicates that the udev daemon is not running.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Check the service by running ps -ef | grep systemd-udevd or by viewing the diagnostic in the Operations Manager Console. Start it by running "systemctl start systemd-udevd" or by clicking the recovery link in the Operations Manager Console.
For root cause analysis, first check the system log file (/var/log/messages), and view any related entries at the time of failure.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers and populates the "Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor" with instances of processors discovered on Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Computers.

This metric is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.
Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The percentage of processor time (for a single processor) is high. System performance may be adversely affected.

Processor time is the time that a single processor spent running a non-idle thread. Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run. This metric is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed.

The monitor threshold is analyzed against an average of values returned in polls to the agent, where the Number of Samples parameter controls the number of samples included in the calculation of the average. The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'
Default Configuration
Overrides can be used to change the parameter values defined above for all instances or for specific instances or groups.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: An unhealthy state indicates that the processor utilization is currently high. This may be caused by an application using excessive processor resources.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: To address high processor time conditions choose one or more of the following options:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Identify processes that are running when the processor time is at the highest. Execute the "top" command or execute "Top 10 CPU Processes" Task from the State View. This task provides a listing of the top CPU consuming processes ordered by CPU usage.
Stop or kill any unnecessary identified processes.
Add processors or physical memory to the computer.
Move applications to one or more additional servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% User Time performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that a single processor spent running code in user mode. Applications and most system utilities execute in user mode.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.
Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% DPC Time performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the percentage of time that a single processor spent receiving and servicing deferred procedure calls (DPCs). DPCs are interrupts that run at a lower priority than standard interrupts. % DPC Time is a component of % Privileged Time because DPCs are executed in privileged mode. If a high % DPC Time is sustained, there may be a processor bottleneck or an application or hardware related issue that can significantly diminish overall system performance.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.
Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% Interrupt Time performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.

This metric exposes the time that a specific processor spent receiving and servicing hardware interrupts. This value is an indirect indicator of the activity of devices that generate interrupts, such as the system clock, the mouse, storage controllers, data communication lines, network interface cards and other peripheral devices. These devices normally interrupt the processor when they have completed a task or require attention. Normal thread execution is suspended during interrupts.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.
Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects performance data for the Processor\% IO Wait Time performance counter. The collected values are accessible in performance views and reports.
This metric exposes the percentage of elapsed time that a single processor was running the idle thread while the system had an outstanding disk I/O request.
The value returned by the agent is the rolling average of the 5 most recent values queried at 1 minute intervals.
Monitoring of individual processors is disabled by default. Enable monitoring by enabling the object discovery named 'Discover Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Processor.'

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The Linux RHEL 8 Management Pack provides the monitoring features that are required to monitor Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 Operating Systems.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This Discovery Rule discovers supported agent information for Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server 8 on x64 computers.
